The intensity of a stimulus is coded not by the amplitude of individual action potentials but by the frequency of firing (rate coding) and the number of neurons activated

Agonists & Antagonists: An agonist is a substance that mimics or enhances the action of a neurotransmitter (e.g., nicotine is an acetylcholine agonist; morphine is an endorphin agonist). An antagonist blocks or reduces the action of a neurotransmitter (e.g., curare blocks acetylcholine receptors; naloxone blocks opioid receptors). Reuptake inhibitors (e.g., SSRIs for serotonin) block the transporter that removes the neurotransmitter from the synaptic cleft, effectively increasing its availability and prolonging its action

Saltatory Conduction: Saltatory conduction refers to the "jumping" of action potentials from one node of Ranvier to the next along myelinated axons. This dramatically increases conduction velocity (up to 120 m/s in large myelinated fibers) compared to continuous conduction in unmyelinated fibers (~1-2 m/s). Demyelinating diseases such as multiple sclerosis disrupt saltatory conduction, slowing or blocking neural transmission

The neuron is the fundamental signaling unit of the nervous system. Although neurons vary widely in shape and size, they share a common structural plan consisting of a cell body, dendrites, and an axon

The resting potential of a neuron is approximately -70 mV , maintained by the sodium-potassium pump (3 Na+ out, 2 K+ in) and selective ion channel permeability. When excitatory inputs depolarize the membrane to the threshold (approximately -55 mV), an action potential is triggered

The absolute refractory period occurs during depolarization and early repolarization, when no stimulus (regardless of intensity) can trigger another action potential. The relative refractory period follows, during which a stronger-than-normal stimulus can trigger an action potential. These periods limit the maximum firing rate and ensure unidirectional propagation of the signal along the axon

Communication between neurons occurs at the synapse , the junction between a presynaptic terminal button and a postsynaptic dendrite (or cell body). The synaptic cleft — a gap of approximately 20-40 nanometers — separates the pre- and postsynaptic membranes. The sequence of synaptic transmission is as follows:

Behavioral genetics investigates the relative contributions of genetic and environmental factors to individual differences in behavior, cognition, and psychopathology. This field provides essential evidence for understanding the biological bases of psychological traits and disorders, and its concepts are heavily tested on the EPPP

Twin studies are the cornerstone method of behavioral genetics. They compare concordance rates (or correlations) between monozygotic (MZ, identical) twins, who share 100% of their DNA, and dizygotic (DZ, fraternal) twins, who share approximately 50% of their segregating genes

Adoption studies separate genetic from environmental contributions by comparing adopted children to both their biological parents (who share genes but not environment) and their adoptive parents (who share environment but not genes). If adopted children more closely resemble their biological parents on a trait, genetic factors are implicated. If they more closely resemble their adoptive parents, environmental factors are implicated. Adoption studies of schizophrenia  provided pivotal evidence for a genetic contribution to the disorder

Memory Consolidation: Consolidation is the process by which newly encoded, fragile memory traces are stabilized and integrated into long-term storage. Synaptic consolidation occurs within hours at the level of individual synapses (involving protein synthesis and structural changes). Systems consolidation occurs over weeks to years, involving the gradual transfer of memory representations from the hippocampus to distributed neocortical networks. Once fully consolidated, memories can be retrieved independently of the hippocampus

Clinical Features of Korsakoff's Syndrome: The hallmark features include severe anterograde amnesia, variable retrograde amnesia, and confabulation — the production of fabricated, distorted, or misinterpreted memories without the conscious intention to deceive. Confabulation occurs because the patient fills memory gaps with plausible-sounding but inaccurate information. Patients may also show apathy, lack of insight (anosognosia), and difficulty with temporal ordering of events. Procedural memory and priming are typically preserved

Hebb's Rule: Donald Hebb (1949) proposed that "cells that fire together wire together" — when a presynaptic neuron repeatedly contributes to firing a postsynaptic neuron, the synaptic connection between them is strengthened. This Hebbian learning rule anticipated the discovery of LTP by over two decades and remains a foundational principle of neural plasticity and memory formation. Hebb also proposed the concept of the "cell assembly" — a network of interconnected neurons that represents a memory and becomes increasingly coordinated through repeated co-activation

Clinical Application — Memory Reconsolidation in Therapy: Reconsolidation theory has informed trauma therapies that aim to reactivate traumatic memories in safe therapeutic conditions, then introduce new, corrective information during the reconsolidation window. This may update the original memory trace rather than simply creating a competing inhibitory memory (as in standard extinction). The approach is still being researched but represents a promising integration of neuroscience and psychotherapy

EPPP Distinction: Wernicke's encephalopathy (acute phase: confusion, ataxia, ophthalmoplegia) and Korsakoff's syndrome (chronic phase: amnesia, confabulation) are often considered a continuum — Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome . Wernicke's is treated emergently with IV thiamine; if untreated, approximately 80% of cases progress to Korsakoff's, which is largely irreversible. The EPPP tests the connection between chronic alcohol use, thiamine deficiency, and the specific memory symptoms of Korsakoff's

The hippocampus , a seahorse-shaped structure in the medial temporal lobe, plays a critical role in the consolidation of new declarative (explicit) memories. It serves as a temporary indexing system that binds together distributed cortical representations of an experience, enabling the gradual transfer of memories to neocortical storage over time

The hippocampus is essential for encoding new episodic memories and spatial navigation (containing "place cells" that fire when an organism occupies a specific location). It is also part of the Papez circuit, which links the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies, anterior thalamus, and cingulate cortex in a circuit important for memory formation

The case of H.M. (Henry Molaison, 1926-2008) is the most important single case in the history of memory neuroscience. In 1953, neurosurgeon William Beecher Scoville performed a bilateral medial temporal lobectomy (removing the hippocampus, amygdala, and surrounding cortex bilaterally) to treat H.M.'s severe epilepsy. The surgery controlled his seizures but produced profound amnesia

Korsakoff's syndrome is a chronic neurological condition caused by severe thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency , most commonly associated with chronic alcohol use disorder. The thiamine deficiency produces damage to the mammillary bodies, dorsomedial thalamus, and periventricular regions — all structures critical to memory circuits

Long-term potentiation (LTP) is the persistent strengthening of synaptic connections following high-frequency stimulation. First described in the hippocampus by Bliss and Lomo (1973), LTP is widely considered the primary cellular mechanism underlying learning and memory

LTP involves several key molecular steps: (1) high-frequency stimulation of the presynaptic neuron releases glutamate, (2) this activates AMPA and NMDA receptors on the postsynaptic neuron, (3) NMDA receptor activation (which requires both glutamate binding and sufficient postsynaptic depolarization) allows calcium influx, (4) calcium triggers intracellular signaling cascades that strengthen the synapse through insertion of additional AMPA receptors and, eventually, structural changes (new dendritic spines)

The amygdala modulates the encoding and consolidation of emotionally arousing memories. It does not store the declarative content of emotional memories but enhances hippocampal consolidation through stress hormone and norepinephrine signaling. This explains why emotionally charged events are generally better remembered — the amygdala amplifies the hippocampal encoding process. Amygdala damage impairs the emotional enhancement of memory without affecting the formation of non-emotional declarative memories

The cerebellum is essential for motor learning, classical conditioning of motor responses (e.g., eyeblink conditioning), and the fine-tuning of skilled movements. Cerebellar damage impairs the acquisition of conditioned motor responses and the performance of skilled procedural tasks

The basal ganglia (particularly the striatum) are critical for habit learning, stimulus-response associations, and the automatization of behaviors through reinforcement. Patients with Huntington's disease (caudate nucleus atrophy) or Parkinson's disease (substantia nigra degeneration) show impaired procedural and habit learning despite relatively preserved declarative memory in early stages

Reconsolidation theory proposes that when a consolidated memory is reactivated (retrieved), it temporarily returns to a labile state and must be reconsolidated to persist. During this reconsolidation window, the memory is vulnerable to modification, disruption, or updating. This has clinical implications for treating PTSD — reactivating a traumatic memory during a therapeutic window (e.g., with propranolol administration or extinction training) may allow the emotional component to be weakened during reconsolidation

passages.section: Recall, Recognition & the Serial Position Effect
passages.passage: Serial Position Effect: The serial position effect describes the tendency to recall items at the beginning and end of a list better than items in the middle. The primacy effect (superior recall of early items) is attributed to greater rehearsal and transfer to long-term memory. The recency effect (superior recall of recent items) is attributed to the items still being active in short-term/working memory. A distractor task between learning and recall eliminates the recency effect but not the primacy effect, supporting the distinction between STM and LTM stores

Misinformation Effect: The misinformation effect occurs when misleading post-event information is incorporated into an individual's memory of the original event. This can take the form of misleading questions, exposure to inaccurate accounts from other witnesses, or suggestive therapeutic techniques. The misinformation effect is more powerful when the original memory is weak, when the misleading information is presented with authority, and when there is a long delay between the event and the misinformation

Clinical Relevance: Proactive interference increases with age and is a significant contributor to age-related memory complaints. Older adults are particularly susceptible to proactive interference because they have accumulated more competing memories and may have reduced inhibitory control. In neuropsychological testing, proactive interference is assessed through paradigms such as the release-from-PI procedure and is a sensitive indicator of frontal lobe dysfunction

passages.section: Recall, Recognition & the Serial Position Effect
passages.passage: EPPP Application: If an EPPP question describes a participant who learns a word list, performs 30 seconds of mental arithmetic, and then recalls the list, the expected finding is that the primacy effect is preserved (early items still recalled well) but the recency effect is eliminated (recent items are no longer in STM). This classic finding supports the Atkinson-Shiffrin dual-store model

passages.section: Recall, Recognition & the Serial Position Effect
passages.passage: Retrieval processes vary in the amount of environmental support they provide. Recall requires generating information from memory with minimal cues (e.g., "Name the four lobes of the cortex"), while recognition requires identifying previously encountered information from a set of alternatives (e.g., multiple-choice questions). Recognition is generally easier because the correct answer serves as its own retrieval cue

passages.section: The Ebbinghaus Forgetting Curve & Interference Theory
passages.passage: Hermann Ebbinghaus (1885) conducted the first systematic study of forgetting using nonsense syllables. His forgetting curve demonstrated that forgetting is most rapid immediately after learning, with the rate of forgetting decelerating over time. Approximately 50% of newly learned material is forgotten within the first hour, and about 70% within 24 hours, but the remaining material is retained relatively stably over longer periods
Interference theory proposes that forgetting occurs because memories compete with one another during retrieval. Two forms of interference are critical for the EPPP:

Cue-dependent forgetting occurs when information is stored in long-term memory but cannot be accessed because the appropriate retrieval cues are absent. This is distinct from trace decay — the memory exists but is temporarily inaccessible. The tip-of-the-tongue (TOT) phenomenon is a vivid example: the person feels certain they know the word, can often recall partial information (first letter, number of syllables), but cannot produce the complete word until the right cue appears

Elizabeth Loftus's research on the misinformation effect demonstrates that post-event information can alter memory for the original event. In her classic studies, participants who watched a video of a car accident and were later asked "How fast were the cars going when they smashed into each other?" (vs. "contacted" or "hit") reported higher speed estimates and were more likely to falsely remember seeing broken glass

The Deese-Roediger-McDermott (DRM) paradigm demonstrates spontaneous false memory formation. Participants study a list of words all related to a non-presented critical lure (e.g., "bed," "rest," "awake," "tired," "dream" — the critical lure being "sleep"). At test, participants frequently recall or recognize the critical lure with high confidence, sometimes claiming to remember specific details of its presentation. This demonstrates that semantic activation during encoding can create false memories that feel phenomenologically real

Source monitoring refers to the process of attributing a memory to its correct source. Source monitoring errors occur when individuals correctly remember information but misattribute its origin — confusing something they imagined with something they actually experienced, something they read with something someone told them, or something one person said with something another person said. These errors are particularly common in children, older adults, and individuals with frontal lobe dysfunction

The recovered memory debate centers on whether traumatic memories can be repressed and later accurately recovered, or whether "recovered" memories are typically false memories created through suggestive therapeutic techniques

Motivated forgetting refers to the concept that individuals may forget information because it is unpleasant, threatening, or anxiety-provoking. Freud's concept of repression posits that traumatic memories are actively pushed out of conscious awareness as a defense mechanism. While there is evidence for intentional suppression of unwanted memories (Anderson & Green's "Think/No-Think" paradigm), the scientific evidence for Freudian repression of entire traumatic events is weak and contested

Absolute Threshold: The absolute threshold is the minimum intensity of a stimulus that can be detected 50% of the time. For example, the absolute threshold for vision is roughly the equivalent of a candle flame visible from 30 miles on a clear dark night. Note that the 50% criterion is key — detection is probabilistic, not all-or-none

Difference Threshold (JND): The difference threshold , or just noticeable difference (JND) , is the minimum difference between two stimuli that can be detected 50% of the time. Weber's Law states that the JND is a constant proportion of the original stimulus intensity (delta I / I = k). For example, if you can just barely notice the difference between a 100g weight and a 102g weight (2% difference), you would need a 4g difference to detect a change from 200g. The Weber fraction (k) is smaller for more sensitive modalities

Trichromatic Theory (Young-Helmholtz): The retina contains three types of cones, each maximally sensitive to a different wavelength: short (blue), medium (green), and long (red). All perceived colors result from the combined activation of these three cone types. This theory explains color mixing and certain forms of color blindness (e.g., dichromacy from the absence of one cone type)

Bottom-Up vs. Top-Down Processing: Bottom-up processing (data-driven) begins with sensory input and builds up to perception without influence from prior knowledge. Top-down processing (concept-driven) uses prior knowledge, expectations, and context to interpret sensory input. Most perception involves an interaction of both. Top-down processing explains why context allows you to read words with missing letters, why ambiguous stimuli are perceived differently depending on expectations, and why cultural background influences perception

Clinical Relevance: Attentional deficits are a core feature of many psychological disorders tested on the EPPP. ADHD involves impairments in sustained attention and executive control of attention. Hemispatial neglect following right parietal stroke represents a dramatic failure of spatial attention (Posner's disengage operation). Anxiety disorders involve attentional bias toward threat-related stimuli, which can be measured with the dot-probe task. Understanding the theoretical models of attention provides the conceptual framework for understanding these clinical presentations

Clinical Application: Signal detection theory applies directly to clinical decision-making. A psychologist conducting a risk assessment must balance the cost of false positives (incorrectly identifying someone as dangerous, leading to unnecessary restriction) against the cost of false negatives (failing to identify a truly dangerous individual). The base rate of the behavior, the severity of consequences, and the clinician's threshold for action all influence the decision criterion
Psychophysics is the study of the relationship between physical stimuli and the psychological sensations they produce. Several foundational concepts from psychophysics are heavily tested on the EPPP

Signal detection theory provides a framework for understanding how decisions are made under conditions of uncertainty, going beyond simple threshold concepts by acknowledging that detection depends on both the sensitivity of the observer and their response criterion (decision bias)

The observer's sensitivity (d-prime) reflects their ability to discriminate signal from noise, independent of response bias. The response criterion (beta) reflects the observer's willingness to say "yes" — a liberal criterion produces more hits but also more false alarms, while a conservative criterion produces fewer false alarms but also more misses. Response criterion shifts depending on the payoff matrix (e.g., a radiologist screening for cancer should adopt a liberal criterion because missing a tumor [miss] is more costly than a false alarm)

Sensory adaptation is the diminished sensitivity to an unchanging stimulus over time. When you first enter a room with a strong odor, the smell is noticeable, but after several minutes, you barely detect it. This occurs because sensory receptors reduce their firing rate in response to constant stimulation. Importantly, pain receptors show minimal adaptation — a biologically adaptive feature that ensures continued attention to potentially harmful stimuli

Light enters the eye through the cornea, passes through the pupil (regulated by the iris), is focused by the lens, and strikes the retina — a thin layer of neural tissue at the back of the eye containing the photoreceptors

Hubel and Wiesel's Nobel Prize-winning research identified feature detectors in the primary visual cortex (V1): simple cells respond to lines and edges at specific orientations and locations; complex cells respond to moving lines at specific orientations regardless of exact position; and hypercomplex cells respond to lines of specific length or endpoints. This hierarchical processing demonstrates how the visual cortex builds complex representations from simple features

Sound waves are converted to neural signals through the mechanical structures of the ear (outer ear, tympanic membrane, ossicles) and the cochlea, where hair cells on the basilar membrane transduce mechanical vibration into electrical signals

Modern understanding: place theory and frequency/volley theory are complementary. Low frequencies are coded primarily by firing rate (frequency theory), high frequencies are coded by the location of maximal basilar membrane displacement (place theory), and intermediate frequencies use both mechanisms
The Gestalt principles describe how the visual system organizes individual elements into coherent wholes ("the whole is different from the sum of its parts"):

Binocular cues (requiring both eyes): retinal disparity (each eye receives a slightly different image; greater disparity = closer object) and convergence (the inward turning of the eyes for near objects). Monocular cues (available from one eye): relative size, interposition (overlap), linear perspective, texture gradient, aerial perspective (haziness), and motion parallax

Attention determines which of the vast amount of incoming sensory information reaches conscious awareness and receives further processing. A central debate in cognitive psychology concerns where in the processing stream selection occurs — early (before meaning is extracted) or late (after full semantic analysis). The major models of attention are frequently tested on the EPPP

Deutsch and Deutsch (1963), later refined by Norman (1968), proposed a late selection model in which all incoming information is fully processed for meaning (semantically analyzed), and selection occurs only at the response/awareness stage. According to this model, the bottleneck is not in perception but in the decision about what to act on or remember. This explains how people can be influenced by the meaning of unattended messages without being consciously aware of them

Sleep Spindles & K-Complexes: Sleep spindles are brief bursts of 12-14 Hz activity generated by the thalamus during NREM Stage 2. They are believed to play a role in memory consolidation and protecting sleep from external disturbances. K-complexes are large, sharp waveforms that also appear in Stage 2; they are thought to represent cortical responses to external stimuli and may function in sleep maintenance

NREM Parasomnias (Disorders of Arousal): Sleepwalking (somnambulism) and night terrors (sleep terrors) occur during NREM Stage 3 (slow-wave sleep), typically in the first third of the night. During night terrors, the individual may sit up screaming with autonomic arousal (tachycardia, sweating) but has no memory of the event. These parasomnias are most common in children and usually resolve with maturation. They should be distinguished from nightmares, which occur during REM sleep

REM Sleep Behavior Disorder (RBD): REM sleep behavior disorder involves loss of the normal muscle atonia during REM sleep, allowing individuals to physically act out their dreams. RBD is a strong prodromal marker for synucleinopathies — a significant percentage of patients with RBD eventually develop Parkinson's disease or Lewy body dementia. This association is high-yield for the EPPP

passages.section: Sleep Across the Lifespan & Deprivation Effects
passages.passage: Sleep Deprivation Effects: Chronic sleep deprivation impairs attention, working memory, decision-making, emotional regulation, and immune function. Sleep-deprived individuals show increased activity in the amygdala and decreased prefrontal cortex regulation, leading to heightened emotional reactivity. Severe prolonged sleep deprivation can produce perceptual disturbances, paranoia, and psychotic-like symptoms. Growth hormone, which is primarily secreted during slow-wave sleep, is also affected — relevant for pediatric growth and recovery from illness

Clinical Application: Exogenous melatonin is used therapeutically for circadian rhythm disorders, jet lag, and as an adjunct for insomnia. The timing of administration is critical: melatonin given in the evening advances the circadian phase (useful for delayed sleep-wake phase disorder), while melatonin given in the morning delays the phase. Blue-light-blocking glasses in the evening can also advance sleep onset by preventing melatonin suppression

Sleep is organized into a cyclic architecture of NREM (non-rapid eye movement) and REM (rapid eye movement) stages, each with characteristic electroencephalographic (EEG) signatures. A complete sleep cycle lasts approximately 90 minutes, with 4-6 cycles occurring per night

As the night progresses, NREM Stage 3 (slow-wave sleep) decreases while REM periods become progressively longer. Most slow-wave sleep occurs in the first third of the night, while most REM sleep occurs in the last third. This distribution has important implications: disruptions to early-night sleep primarily affect slow-wave sleep (and declarative memory consolidation), while disruptions to late-night sleep primarily affect REM sleep (and procedural/emotional memory processing)

Circadian rhythms are endogenous biological cycles with a period of approximately 24 hours that regulate sleep-wake cycles, hormone secretion, body temperature, and other physiological processes. The master circadian clock is the suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) , located in the anterior hypothalamus directly above the optic chiasm

The SCN receives light information directly from the retina via the retinohypothalamic tract (using specialized melanopsin-containing retinal ganglion cells), allowing it to synchronize the internal clock with the external light-dark cycle. The SCN projects to the pineal gland , which secretes melatonin during darkness. Melatonin promotes sleep onset and is suppressed by light exposure, particularly blue-wavelength light

Insomnia disorder involves difficulty initiating or maintaining sleep, or early morning awakening, at least three nights per week for at least three months, causing significant distress or functional impairment. Cognitive-behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I) is the first-line treatment and includes stimulus control, sleep restriction, sleep hygiene education, cognitive restructuring, and relaxation training

Narcolepsy is characterized by excessive daytime sleepiness and may include cataplexy (sudden loss of muscle tone triggered by strong emotions), hypnagogic/hypnopompic hallucinations, and sleep paralysis. Type 1 narcolepsy involves deficiency of hypocretin (orexin) , a neuropeptide produced by the lateral hypothalamus that promotes wakefulness. The loss of hypocretin-producing neurons is believed to result from autoimmune destruction

Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) involves repeated episodes of upper airway collapse during sleep, producing apneas (cessation of breathing for 10+ seconds) or hypopneas (partial airway obstruction). OSA disrupts sleep architecture, reduces oxygen saturation, and is associated with cardiovascular disease, cognitive impairment, and excessive daytime sleepiness. Treatment includes CPAP (continuous positive airway pressure)

Subcortical: Refers to structures situated below the cerebral cortex, including the thalamus, hypothalamus, basal ganglia, limbic system structures, brainstem, and cerebellum. These regions are phylogenetically older and more critical for survival-related functions than cortical structures

Cerebellar Damage: Produces ataxia (loss of coordination), dysarthria (slurred speech), intention tremor (tremor that worsens as the hand approaches a target, in contrast to Parkinson's resting tremor), nystagmus (involuntary eye movements), and gait instability. Cerebellar damage does NOT cause paralysis

Clinical Significance: Olfaction (smell) is the only sensory modality that does not relay through the thalamus. Olfactory information travels directly from the olfactory bulb to the piriform cortex and amygdala. This is a frequently tested fact on the EPPP

passages.section: Clinical Significance of Basal Ganglia Dysfunction
passages.passage: Clinical Significance: The direct pathway through the basal ganglia facilitates movement (excitatory net effect), while the indirect pathway inhibits movement (inhibitory net effect). Parkinson's disease (too little dopamine) results in difficulty initiating movement. Huntington's disease (loss of inhibitory neurons) results in excessive, uncontrolled movement

Clinical Significance: The RAS is clinically important for understanding disorders of consciousness. Coma results from bilateral cortical damage or damage to the RAS. Damage to specific brainstem regions can produce "locked-in syndrome," where patients are conscious but unable to move or communicate except through eye movements

EPPP Application: Lesion studies are frequently tested. Remember: lateral hypothalamus lesions produce "lateral leanness" (aphagia/weight loss), while ventromedial hypothalamus lesions produce "ventromedial voluminosity" (hyperphagia/obesity). These mnemonics appear on many EPPP study resources

Subcortical structures are brain regions located beneath the cerebral cortex that perform vital functions including relaying sensory information, regulating homeostasis, coordinating movement, and mediating emotion and memory. For the EPPP, it is essential to know the key subcortical structures, their locations, their functions, and the clinical consequences of their damage

The thalamus is a large, egg-shaped structure sitting atop the brainstem at the center of the brain. It serves as the brain's primary sensory relay station, routing incoming sensory information to the appropriate cortical areas

The hypothalamus is a small structure (approximately the size of an almond) located below the thalamus. Despite its small size, it is critical for maintaining homeostasis and regulating the endocrine system through its connection with the pituitary gland

The limbic system is a collection of interconnected structures surrounding the thalamus that mediate emotion, motivation, learning, and memory. While the exact boundaries of the limbic system are debated, the following structures are consistently included:

A seahorse-shaped structure in the medial temporal lobe that is essential for the consolidation of new declarative (explicit) memories -- the transfer of information from short-term to long-term storage
An almond-shaped structure anterior to the hippocampus, the amygdala is the brain's "fear center" and is critical for emotional processing, particularly fear conditioning and threat detection
The basal ganglia are a group of subcortical nuclei involved in the initiation, execution, and modulation of voluntary movement, as well as procedural learning and habit formation
The brainstem connects the cerebral hemispheres to the spinal cord and controls vital autonomic functions. It consists of three major divisions:

The cerebellum ("little brain") is located posterior to the brainstem and contains more neurons than the rest of the brain combined. Although comprising only 10% of brain volume, it contains approximately 50% of the brain's neurons

The reticular activating system is a network of neurons extending through the brainstem core from the medulla to the midbrain. It plays a critical role in regulating consciousness, arousal, and the sleep-wake cycle
